marketNews.title: Car Sales February 2024 Remain Weak; ASII Market Share Increases
marketNews.content:
Car sales wholesale in Indonesia in February 2024 recorded 70,656 units, up 1.5% month-on-month (MoM) but down 18.8% year-on-year (YoY). The monthly growth was mainly supported by increased sales of brands under Astra International (ASII), such as Toyota and Daihatsu. Other brands like Wuling (-44.9% MoM), Hyundai (-19.2% MoM), Suzuki (-18.7% MoM) and Mitsubishi (-8.4% MoM) experienced declines.

ASII itself recorded wholesale sales of 41,240 units in February 2024, up 8.6% MoM but down 11.4% YoY. The relatively better result compared with the industry raised ASII’s market share to 58.4% in February 2024 (January 2024: 54.6%; February 2023: 53.5%).

Cumulatively for the first two months of 2024, wholesale car sales in Indonesia reached only 140,275 units, down 22.6% YoY. All brands except Wuling posted lower sales in the first two months of 2024. The result meets only 12.7% of the 2024 target set by Gaikindo at the 1.1 million-unit level. By comparison, the realizations for the first two months of 2022 and 2023 met 15.8% and 18% of the respective year’s total sales.

Marketing Director of PT Toyota-Astra Motor (TAM), Anton Jimmi Suwandy, said that the weakening of car sales in early 2024 was pressured by postponed purchases from retail and fleet customers ahead of the election. In addition, the Business Association reported that the decline was also triggered by the government’s delay in extending the VAT-zero incentive for electric vehicles. As information, electric-vehicle sales contributed 3.4% of wholesale car sales in 4Q23.

Key Takeaway
Although sales in the coming months may recover after the election and with a rebound in EV sales, we assess that there remains a risk that the 2024 target of 1.1 million units set by Gaikindo may not be achieved.

The relatively better performance of ASII was positively received by the market, with the company’s share price rising 2.43% to IDR 5,275 per share on Thursday (14/3). Currently ASII trades at a 7.0× 1-Year Forward P/E, similar to the level during the Covid-19 pandemic. ASII also plans to propose a final dividend of IDR 421 per share, indicating a final dividend yield of about 8% on Thursday (14/3).

Related stocks: ASII, IMAS, DRMA, AUTO.

marketNews.title: BBCA Distributes Final Dividend with Indicated Yield 2.2%
marketNews.content:
BBCA: Shareholders of Bank Central Asia approved a final dividend of IDR 227.5 per share, amounting to IDR 28 trillion in total. The cum-dividend and payment date have not been announced. Using the closing price of BBCA on Thursday (14/3) at IDR 10,325 per share, the implied final dividend yield is 2.2%. Previously, BBCA also distributed an interim dividend of IDR 42.5 per share (IDR 5.2 trillion) in December 2023. Consequently, BBCA’s total dividend payout ratio for fiscal year 2023 is 68.4%.

INCO: Vale Indonesia plans a rights issue of approximately 603.5 million new shares, resulting in a dilution of up to 5.73%. The issue price and ratio have not been disclosed. The corporate action is part of fulfilling INCO’s divestment obligation to MIND ID. Proceeds will be used for capital expenditures and working capital. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders meeting on 19 April 2024.

DGNS: Diagnos Laboratorium Utama intends a rights issue of 921 million new shares (73.7% of total), leading to a dilution of up to 42%. The issue price is set at IDR 505 per share. The majority of the proceeds will be used to acquire 98% of the shares of Asa Ren Pte. Ltd. through an inbreng scheme and share purchase. Asa Ren Pte. Ltd. owns PT Asa Ren Global Nusantara, a company engaged in the trade of laboratory, pharmaceutical and medical equipment. DGNS controlling shareholder Bundamedik (BMHS) will transfer part of its rights to Asa Ren Pte. Ltd. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders meeting on 19 April 2024.

DOID: Delta Dunia Makmur reported a net profit of USD 36 million (+26% YoY) in 2023, supported by revenue growth of +18% YoY to USD 1.8 billion. Operationally, overburden removal grew +14% YoY, while production volume increased in Indonesian mines (+10% YoY) and Australian mines (+28% YoY). In 4Q23, DOID posted revenue of USD 470 million (-7% QoQ) and net profit of USD 16.4 million (-3% QoQ).

ENRG: Energi Mega Persada’s Investor Relations Advisor, Herwin W. Hidayat, said the company targets oil-gas production growth of +10-15% YoY in 2024. In 2023, the company recorded an average daily production of 5,700 barrels of oil per day (BOPD) and 165 million standard cubic feet of gas per day (MMSCFD). ENRG allocated a capex of USD 150 million for 2024, intended for development drilling, gas pipeline construction and additional production facilities.

ACST: Acset Indonusa plans to add civil construction activities for mining and related excavation activities to its business. Management stated the expansion is based on the continued growth of the mining industry. ACST also has access to potential mining construction projects through its parent United Tractors (UNTR). With the new line of business, ACST’s asset value is projected to grow +10.46% from 2024 to 2028, reaching IDR 1.9 trillion.

IMPC: Impack Pratama Industri’s controlling shareholder PT Tunggal Jaya Investama sold 550.5 million IMPC shares at IDR 390 per share on 7 March 2024, amounting to a total transaction value of IDR 215 billion. The transaction aims to increase the free-float of IMPC shares. After the transaction, PT Tunggal Jaya Investama’s ownership in IMPC decreased from 43.91% to 42.89%.

ID Food: The company has not yet realized the import assignment of 20,000 tons of beef from Brazil this year due to budget and licensing issues.

BP Tapera: Commissioner Heru Pudyo Nugroho said the agency will review the scheme of fixed-interest mortgage loans with a 35-year tenor, involving stakeholders such as PT Sarana Multigriya Finansial (SMF) and Bank Tabungan Negara (BBTN).

DPR: The House of Representatives’ Commission VII requested that the oil-lifting target of SKK Migas be revised from 1 million barrels per day by 2030, deeming the current target unrealistic. In 2023, actual oil lifting reached 605,500 barrels per day, below the 2023 APBN target of 660,000 bpd and the 2023 work-program target of 621,000 bpd. SKK Migas head Dwi Soetjipto indicated the target may be delayed by 2-3 years.

Brent: Brent crude futures rose +2.6% to USD 84.03 per barrel on Wednesday (13/3) after the U.S. Energy Information Administration reported crude oil inventories for the week ending 8 March 2024 fell by 1.5 million barrels, exceeding the consensus estimate of a 1.3 million-barrel draw. The EIA also noted gasoline inventories fell by 5.7 million barrels, well above the consensus estimate of a 1.9 million-barrel draw.

Bank Indonesia: The central bank recorded a +1.1% YoY increase in retail sales in Indonesia in January 2024 (December 2023: +0.2% YoY). This marks eight consecutive months of year-on-year growth. On a monthly basis, retail sales fell -3.5% MoM, reflecting post-holiday demand normalization and unfavourable weather. Bank Indonesia forecasts retail sales in February 2024 to grow +3.6% YoY, but still contract MoM.

OJK: The Financial Services Authority’s chief executive, Dian Ediana Rae, announced that the regulator will soon issue regulations on the transparency of the basic credit interest rate (SBDK) for conventional banks, covering the components of the base rate, overhead costs and profit margin. Banks will be required to report SBDK details.

Jakarta: The Minister of Home Affairs, Tito Karnavian, said the government proposes that the Jakarta agglomeration administration be placed under the vice-president’s authority, to be regulated in the Special Region of Jakarta Bill (RUU DKJ).

Customs: Soekarno-Hatta Customs will limit the amount of goods that passengers can bring, covering shoes, footwear, bags, textiles, electronic devices, mobile phones, headsets and tablets. The restriction takes effect on 10 March 2024, based on Permendag No. 36/2023. Customs Director Gatot Sugeng Wibowo warned the measure will affect passenger-brought imports.
